Name: Vai
researchNotes:
Under Family: Script fails to be defined by a singular source (such as N'ko), multiple glyphs that are non-descendent form the syllabary. 
Under Glyphs: Check notes of the 1962 conference at the University of Liberia, apparently most scholars find need for only forty to sixty characters.
parent: Invented, but possible stimulus diffusion from Cherokee syllabary via Austin Curtis
children: Possible inspiration through stimulus diffusion for Mende, Loma, and Kpelle syllabaries
imageDescription: The greater part of the modern Vai syllabary. Eh and oh are the open vowels [ɛ, ɔ]. The letter "ɖ" is an error for ɗ. The jg on the bottom row is [ŋɡ]. Not shown are syllables beginning with g, h, w, m, n, ny, ng [ŋ], and vowels.
imageCitation: https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Vai.gif

Name: Kanji
description: While the Joyo standards describe approximately 2000 common use kanji, used for government documents and taught in school "the number of different kanji employed in newspapers and magazines in general is approximately 3200-3300" (Daniels and Bright, 1996, 210). Furthermore Omniglot describes between 5000-10000 kanji used in Japanese writing, the number is most likely higher if one were to account for every possible usage of kanji, for the reason of variability "Number of Glyphs" is said to be 2000.
imageDescription: An excerpt from Nihon Shoki (720 AD) written entierly in Kaji
imageCitation: By Unknown author - http://www.emuseum.jp/cgi/pkihon.cgi?SyoID=4&ID=w012&SubID=s000, Public Domain, https://commons.wikimedia.org/w/index.php?curid=6745277

Sources.author: Coulmas, Florian
Sources.book: The Blackwell Encyclopedia of Writing Systems

Name: Yi
description: While modern Yi is being proposed as a syllabary of 819 characters the Yi tribes have been subjected to separation throughout a majority of their history, thus this entry can be assumed as a collection of a longer history of Yi writing that dates back to classical Yi and into modern reformations of Yi.

While radicals were used in Classical Yi the use of radicals has become less prevalent in the modern syllabic interpretation due to multiple readings of a single syllable (read m̥ and m under Ding et al. 91:446 in Daniels and Bright, 1991, 240)
imageDescription: A Yi manuscript from 1814
imageCitation: Wikipedia public domain Yi Script

Sources.author: Shi, Dingxu

Name: Mende
inventor: Kisimi Kamara (traditionally credited with creating this in 1921). The script may have been started by Mohamed Turay in 1917 (Rovenchak & Glavy).
researchNotes: Also known as Kikakui. A Roman script developed ca. 1940 contributed to the decline of use, but it is still in use (Tuchscherer 1995), despite claims to the contrary.
imageDescription: A picture of a leaf in the notebooks of blacksmith Bokari Kanneh, written in the 1950s and acquired by Dr. Konrad Tuchscherer in March of 1994, and donated to Yale in 2009. (Permission pending)
imageCitation: https://digitalorientalist.com/2019/04/12/minding-mende/
